required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evident, Occult and no Demonstrated USI and UDS Findings in Women With ≥Stage II Cystocele
clinical_study.official_title: Prevalence Rates of Evident, Occult and no Demonstrated Urodynamic Stress Incontinence and Their Clinical and Urodynamic Findings in Women With ≥Stage II Cystocele

brief_summary.textblock: Prevalence rates of urodynamic urinary incontinence (USI) subtypes and their related clinical and urodynamic findings in women with ≥ pelvic organ prolapse quantification stage II cystocele are important for clinical consultation, especially for occult USI. Misdiagnosis of occult USI before cystocele repair might lead to occurrence of de novo stress urinary incontinence after cystocele repair. Thus, the aim of this study was to elucidate the above findings and between-group associations.

detailed_description.textblock: Between November 2011 and January 2017, medical records of all women with ≥stage II cystocele who underwent urodynamic studies in a medical center were reviewed. ANOVA test and post-hoc testing with bonferroni's correction were used for statistical analysis. USI is noted during filling cystometry and is defined as the involuntary leakage of urine during increased abdominal pressure, in the absence of a detrusor contraction. The recruited patients with cystocele were classified into three groups (i.e.,evident USI, occult USI and no demonstrated USI) according to pad weight results before and after prolapse reduction.

primary_outcome.description: USI note before reduction of prolapse
USI note after reduction of prolapse

clinical_study.condition: Urodynamic Stress Incontinence in Severe Cystocele Women

arm_group.description: Between November 2011 and January 2017, medical records of all women with ≥stage II cystocele who underwent urodynamic studies in a medical center were reviewed. USI is noted during filling cystometry and is defined as the involuntary leakage of urine during increased abdominal pressure, in the absence of a detrusor contraction.

Between November 2011 and January 2017, medical records of all women with ≥stage II cystocele who underwent urodynamic studies in a medical center were reviewed. USI is noted during filling cystometry and is defined as the involuntary leakage of urine during increased abdominal pressure, in the absence of a detrusor contraction after prolapse reduction by vaginal gauze.
Between November 2011 and January 2017, medical records of all women with ≥stage II cystocele who underwent urodynamic studies in a medical center were reviewed. No USI was noted in this group.

intervention.description: Urodynamic study: including uroflowmetry, filling cystometry, voiding cystometry, and urethral pressure profile

study_pop.textblock: Women with cystocele more than stage II

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Age >20y/o
2. Cystocele > stage II
3. Complete urodynamic study
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Pregnancy
2. Urinary tract infection
3. Previous pelvic reconstruction surgery
